description: Flax (Linum usitatissimum) is a versatile plant cultivated for its strong, bast fibers, which are used to produce linen textiles, and also for its oil-rich seeds (linseed). As a fiber crop, flax is one of the oldest known, valued for producing cool, absorbent, and durable linen fabrics. Specific varieties are grown optimized for fiber production, typically taller and less branched than oilseed varieties.
seasons: Cool-season annual; typically planted in early spring and harvested in late summer.

nutrition.calories: Flaxseeds: 534 kcal per 100g. Linseed Oil: 884 kcal per 100g.

healthBenefits: Excellent source of alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), a plant-based omega-3 fatty acid.
Rich in dietary fiber (both soluble and insoluble), aiding digestion and promoting satiety.
Good source of lignans, which have antioxidant and phytoestrogenic properties.
May help lower cholesterol levels and reduce risk of heart disease.

potentialAllergies.name: Flaxseed Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: Allergy to flaxseed can occur, with symptoms ranging from hives and itching to anaphylaxis in severe cases. It may also cause digestive upset in some individuals if consumed in large amounts without adequate water due to high fiber content.

potentialAllergies.name: Cyanogenic Glycosides (Raw/Unripe Seeds)
potentialAllergies.details: Raw or unripe flaxseeds contain small amounts of cyanogenic glycosides, but these are largely inactivated by processing (e.g., grinding, baking, heating). Consuming large quantities of raw seeds is not recommended.

cultivationProcess: Flax grown for fiber involves planting densely to encourage tall, straight stems with minimal branching. It is harvested by pulling the entire plant or cutting close to the ground. The stalks then undergo retting (a process using moisture and microbes to separate fibers from the woody stem), scutching (crushing stems and removing woody parts), and hackling (combing fibers) to prepare them for spinning.
growthDuration: Approximately 90-100 days from planting to fiber harvest. Fiber flax is harvested earlier than oilseed flax, typically when stems start to yellow and seeds are immature.
sustainabilityTips: Requires fewer pesticides and herbicides than crops like cotton.
Can be part of sustainable crop rotation systems, improving soil structure.
All parts of the plant can be used; seeds for oil/food, straw for paper or composites, further reducing waste.
Retting process can be water-intensive; dew retting is a more sustainable alternative to water retting.
carbonFootprintInfo: The carbon footprint of linen production is influenced by farming practices, retting methods (water vs. dew retting), energy used in fiber processing (scutching, spinning, weaving), and transportation. Organic and locally processed flax have a lower footprint.
originAndDomesticationHistory: Flax (Linum usitatissimum) is one of the oldest cultivated crops, domesticated in the Fertile Crescent region (Near East) around 7,000-8,000 BCE, primarily for its fiber to produce linen. Ancient Egyptians extensively used linen for clothing, sails, and burial shrouds. Its cultivation for fiber spread throughout Europe and Asia. While oilseed flax also has ancient origins, fiber production was historically dominant.

climaticRequirements.temperature: Cool-season crop. Optimal growing temperatures are 10-20°C. Tolerates light frost during early growth stages. High temperatures during flowering can reduce yield and oil quality.
climaticRequirements.rainfall: Requires moderate rainfall, around 400-750mm during the growing season, well-distributed. Adequate moisture is crucial during germination, flowering, and seed development.
climaticRequirements.altitude: Adaptable to various altitudes, primarily grown in temperate regions.

soilPreferences: Prefers well-drained, medium-textured loamy soils with good organic matter content and a slightly acidic to neutral pH (5.5-7.0). Does not tolerate waterlogged or heavy clay soils well.
irrigationAndWaterNeeds: Often grown rain-fed in areas with sufficient cool-season rainfall. Supplemental irrigation may be necessary during dry spells, especially at critical growth stages, to ensure good yields and oil content.
plantingAndHarvestCycles: Seeds are sown densely in early spring. Plants grow tall and slender. Harvesting for fiber occurs when the lower part of the stem begins to yellow and seeds are immature (about 30-40 days after flowering). Plants are pulled up by the roots or cut close to the ground to maximize fiber length. Stalks are then dried and undergo retting.
pestAndDiseaseManagement: Pests include flax flea beetles, cutworms, and armyworms. Diseases such as rust, pasmo, and Fusarium wilt can affect flax. Crop rotation, resistant varieties, and good field sanitation are key management practices for fiber flax.
postHarvestHandling: After harvesting, flax stalks undergo retting (dew, water, or chemical) to loosen the fibers. Then, processes like breaking/scutching (to remove woody core) and hackling (to comb and separate fibers) prepare the long linen fibers for spinning into yarn. Short fibers (tow) are used for coarser products.
majorProducingCountriesOrRegions: European Union (France, UK, Belgium for fiber flax)
marketValueAndGlobalDemand: Flaxseed has a growing global market, driven by demand for its nutritional benefits (omega-3s, fiber, lignans) in human food products and dietary supplements. Linseed oil is widely used in industrial applications (paints, varnishes, linoleum) and as an edible oil. Flax fiber for linen production also has a stable market.
